effector.name: FF-type alpha motoneurons
effector.notes: run; generate large force, poor efficiency; biggest motoneurons, type IIB extrafusal muscle fibers; affected by static beta motoneurons

effector.name: FR-type alpha motoneurons
effector.notes: walk; type IIA extrafusal muscle fibers; affected by static beta motoneurons

effector.name: S-type alpha motoneurons
effector.notes: stand; type I muscle fibers; little force, metabolically efficient, affected by dynamic beta motoneurons

effector.name: Beta motoneurons
effector.function: affect both extrafusal and intrafusal muscle fibers

effector.name: beta dynamic motoneurons
effector.notes: type I extrafusal muscle fibers and the intrafusal bag1 fiber

effector.name: beta static motoneurons
effector.notes: type IIA or IIB extrafusal fibers and the intrafusal bag2 fiber

effector.name: Gamma motoneurons
effector.notes: intrafusal muscle fibers, muscle tonus, additional contracts to maintain sensitivity in stretched state; originate in pontine RF

effector.name: gamma dynamic motoneurons
effector.function: contract muscle spindles from both ends

effector.name: gamma static motoneurons
effector.function: contract muscle spindles from both ends
effector.notes: intrafusal bag2 fiber and the nuclear chain fibers

effector.name: preganglionic paravertebral sympathetic
effector.notes: close to vertebral, fibers ascend/descend to reach all spinal cord levels

effector.name: preganglionic parasympathetic spinal
effector.function: spinal cord long fibers to parasympathetic ganglia

effector.name: preganglionic parasympathetic cranial
effector.function: cranial nerves III, VII, IX and X long fibers to parasympathetic ganglia
effector.notes: eye iris, lacrimal/submandibular/subingual glands, thorax, abdomen, GI tract

effector.name: postganglionic sympathetic motoneurons
effector.function: muscles and skin, pre/post - temporal summation and spatial summation
effector.notes: one-to-many, wide-spread, long and unmyelinated, NE

effector.name: postganglionic parasympathetic motoneurons
effector.function: visceral activity and repose, short, local
effector.notes: from ganglia in/on wall of organ

receptor.name: Muscle spindles
receptor.function: skeletal muscle, stretch by muscle length, fast

receptor.name: Dynamic nuclear bag fibers
receptor.function: report rate of change of muscle length

receptor.name: Merkel disk receptors
receptor.function: responds to pressure on skin; vibration 5-15 Hz, static (sustained) touch/pressure
receptor.notes: epidermis of glabrous skin; respond to slight change in skin surface; high resolution tactile discrimination, mechanoceptors in hairless skin and mucosa, pressure and texture, slowly adapting, sustained response, low threshold; weak position and strong velocity - irregular discharge, type I, hairy/hairless skin

receptor.name: Meissner corpuscles
receptor.function: responds to vibration; vibration 20-50 Hz; dynamic touch/pressure
receptor.notes: dermis of glabrous skin; tactile, texture, rapidly adapting, superficial papillary receptor, low threshold, especially sensitive to light touch - like fingers and lips

receptor.name: Hair follicle receptors
receptor.function: responds to hair displacement; touch, hairy skin velocity
receptor.notes: slowly adapting, low threshold; peritrichial endings - nerve plexus wrapped around hair roots; large hair follicles, slow and rapid movement of hairs and deflection of the skin

receptor.name: Ruffini corpuscles
receptor.function: responds to pressure on skin; stretching of skin, crude touch
receptor.notes: end-bulbs of Krause - dermis of both hairy and glabrous skin and Ruffini - lips, tongue, and genitals; deep receptors, slowly adapting, low threshold; strong position and weak velocity receptors - regular discharge, type II, hairy/hairless skin

receptor.name: Pacinian corpuscles
receptor.function: responds to vibration; vibration 60-400 Hz, deep
receptor.notes: deep layers of dermis in both hairy and glabrous skin; greater signal from more massive or rapid deformation; deep receptors, subcutaneous tissue, viscera, rapidly adapting, low threshold; transient receptors, connective tissue, vibration, intrafusal muscles, tonic proprioceptive endings, flower-spray type

receptor.name: C fiber nociceptors
receptor.function: responsible for the second, burning pain

receptor.name: tactile C fibers
receptor.notes: includes CT fibres, also known as C low-threshold mechanoreceptors (CLTM), which are unmyelinated afferents found in human hairy skin, and have a low mechanical threshold less than 5 milliNewtons; have moderate adaptation and may exhibit fatigue on repetitive stimulation and after discharges for several seconds after a stimulus

receptor.name: C mechano- and metabo- receptors in muscles or joints
receptor.function: responsible for muscle exercise, burn and cramp

fiber.notes: type Ia,Ib; motoneurons, touch, position and velocity
muscle spindle primary sensory endings; extrafusal muscles, Meissner's corpuscles; annulospiral endings, length and velocity

fiber.name: alpha motoneurons
fiber.notes: extrafusal muscle fibers, skeletal movements, brainstem/spinal cord

fiber.function: report load being applied to muscle, stretching of skin

fiber.notes: type II; fine touch, kinesthesia, muscle spindle secondary endings
length only; secondary afferents, flower spray endings

fiber.name: beta motoneurons
fiber.function: skeleto-fusimotor, intrafusal fibers and collaterals to extrafusal muscle fibers, muscle spindles, increase dynamic sensitivity of ending

fiber.notes: skeletal muscle tone, contract muscle spindles from both ends, fusimotor gamma neurons, affect Ia/II

type III; thinly-myelinated; noxious receptors - first/fast, sharp, well-localized pain; cold receptors - temperature, high-threshold mechano/heat, phasic; pressure - rapidly adapting mechanosensitive, directional selectivity, crude touch
myelinated, ACh, sympathetic only in T1-L3, IML

fiber.function: pain, touch, pressure, temperature, postganglionic autonomic

tract.name: medial lemniscus system
tract.function: transmits touch, vibration sense, proprioception data

tract.name: posterior column system
tract.brief: conscious upper body mechanical and lower body cutaneous perception
tract.synonyms: dorsal column, Reils band, Reils ribbon
tract.function: two point discrimination (fine touch, fine pressure - MC), pressure (deep receptors - PC), vibration (PC), conscious proprioception (MS)
tract.notes: alpha/beta mechanoreceptors, conscious; discrimination of those sensations that an animal must explore actively

tract.name: fasciculus cuneatus tract
tract.function: upper body well-localized discriminative proprioception, fine touch
tract.source: upper trunk, forelimb deep structures and skin
tract.notes: muscle afferents and cutaneous mechanoreceptors (C1-T6 dermatomes); thoracic-toward-contralateral and cervical slices

path.pathway: geniohyoid (C1), head top (C2), head back above neck (C3) to S1 medial

path.function: conscious sensations of neck, trunk, and extremities
path.pathway: neck (C4), trunk (T1-T6), and extremities - arms (C5-T2) to S1 lateral

tract.name: fasciculus gracilis tract
tract.function: lower body well-localized discriminative fine touch
tract.notes: sacral-toward-contralateral and lumbar slices; mostly cutaneous (proprioception via CLN)

path.function: epicritic, kinesthetic, and conscious proprioceptive information from lower body
path.pathway: receptors of thoracic and lower limbs, T7-CX to neocortex BA 3b, medial

tract.name: spinocervical tract
tract.function: static position, Ruffini endings
tract.source: receptors of thoracic and lower limbs, T7-CX
tract.notes: thoracic-toward-contralateral and cervical slices

path.function: tactile/pressure pathway from the spinal cord to sensory cortex
path.pathway: tactile/pressure to S1

path.function: four-neuron, fast-conducting, tactile/pressure pathway from the spinal cord to sensory cortex
path.pathway: tactile/pressure to S1

path.function: alerts about presence of cutaneous stimuli that might represent danger, necessitating flight
path.pathway: cutaneous stimuli to PAG

tract.name: anterolateral system
tract.function: conveys pain, temperature (protopathic sensation), and crude touch from the periphery to the brain

tract.name: trigeminothalamic system
tract.function: all somatosensory submodalities from head

tract.name: anterior trigeminothalamic tract
tract.function: awareness of the exact location of the painful stimulus; pain, temperature, and crude touch pathway

path.pathway: head, face and intraoral structures nociceptors to spinal trigeminal nucleus
nociceptors of cranial nerves VII to spinal trigeminal nucleus
nociceptors of cranial nerves IX,X to spinal trigeminal nucleus
nociceptors of cranial nerves X to spinal trigeminal nucleus
spinal trigeminal nucleus to S1

tract.name: dorsal trigeminal tract
tract.function: immediate awareness of a painful sensation; pressure and tactile discrimination sensation

path.function: face dull, burning pain, deep, aching pain, temperature and crude touch
path.pathway: head, face and intraoral structures to Precentral Cortex

path.function: face dull, burning pain, deep, aching pain, temperature and crude touch
path.pathway: head, face and intraoral structures to Precentral Cortex
marginal nucleus to insula
marginal nucleus to frontal lobe

tract.name: paleospinothalamic system
tract.function: transmits pain mainly from the peripheral slow-chronic type C pain fibers; transmits information to thalamus about pain, temperature, itch and crude touch
tract.notes: conscious; cervical-anterior-toward-contralateral, thoracic, lumbar, sacral-lateral slices

tract.name: anterior spinothalamic tract
tract.function: pain, temperature, light touch (tactile sensibility), two-point discrimination, stereognosis
tract.source: skin - slow pain, temperature, slightly tactile

path.pathway: head and body MD,MC,PC,HF receptors to S1

tract.name: lateral spinothalamic tract
tract.function: pain, temperature

path.pathway: head and body FN,RC receptors to marginal nucleus
pain to insula
pain to frontal lobe

tract.name: tract of Lissauer
tract.synonyms: fasciculus of Lissauer, tract/zone of Lissauer, dorsolateral fasciculus, posterolateract tract, dorsolateral tract
tract.function: fast pain; intraspinal, discriminative pain and temperature information - location, intensity and quality
tract.notes: pain duration equals to stimulus duration; joins spinothalamic tract

path.function: autonomic and homeostatic functions, initial sharp localization of pain
path.pathway: body to hypothalamus and neocortex

path.function: from lateral LSN; joins fasciculus cuneatus; initial sharp localization of pain
path.pathway: upper body to neocortex BA 3b

path.function: from medial LSN; joins fasciculus gracilis; initial sharp localization of pain
path.pathway: lower body to neocortex BA 3b

tract.name: spinoreticular system
tract.function: automatic responses to pain

tract.name: spinomedulloreticular tract
tract.function: automatic responses to pain

path.function: automatic responses to pain; attentional and alerting mechanisms
path.pathway: viceral pain to spinal cord to medullary reticular formation; visceral and somatic pain to MRF

tract.name: spinopontoreticular tract
tract.function: automatic responses to pain

path.function: exerts excitatory influence predominantly on pontine reticular nuclei to facilitate contraction of extensor muscles of limb and trunk
path.pathway: crude touch/vibration to spinal cord to pontine reticular formation to thalamus; utilizes four levels of neurons

tract.name: spinotectal tract
tract.function: spinovisual reflexes; head/eye movement toward stimulus source
tract.notes: arises in the anterolateral column
tract.source: free nerve endings; crude touch, temperature, pain

path.function: Head and eye attention to non-visual stimuli
path.pathway: crude touch to nucleus proprius to superior colliculus

tract.name: spinolimbic system
tract.function: connect spinal cord with limbic structures

tract.name: spinohypothalamic tract
tract.brief: autonomic body pain transfer to hypothalamus
tract.function: provide nociceptive information to a variety of nuclei throughout the diencephalon and brainstem bilaterally
tract.notes: nociception integration, from C-fibers innervating muscles

path.pathway: pain fibers to spinal integrator LSN
pain fibers to lateral nucleus
pain fibers to dorsomedial nucleus

path.function: affect appetite, autonomic and homeostatic functions, and related motivational and affective responses to autonomic function
path.pathway: pain fibers to anterior hypothalamus
pain fibers to anterior hypothalamus

path.function: affect blood volume or blood pressure
path.pathway: pain fibers to anterior hypothalamus

tract.name: spinosolitary tract
tract.brief: autonomic body pain transfer to parabrachial nucleus
tract.function: central transmission of visceronoceptive messages
tract.notes: visceronociception, short-latency nociceptive input

path.pathway: pain fibers to spinal integrator LSN

path.function: autonomic regulation of of stress response to painful visceral stimuli
path.pathway: pain fibers to solitary nucleus to parabrachial nucleus

tract.name: spinomesencephalic tract
tract.function: ascending pain and temperature fibers of the spinothalamic tract also send information to the PAG

path.pathway: activates enkephalin-releasing neurons that project to raphe nuclei, descending to inhibitory interneurons located in Laminae II

tract.name: spinocerebellar system
tract.function: spinal cord to cerebellum

tract.name: spinometencephalic system
tract.function: spinal cord to intermediate nucleus to cerebellum

tract.name: spinoolivary tract
tract.brief: automatic activity of head, neck and upper limbs
tract.function: automatic movements of head, neck and upper limb
tract.source: proprioception information from muscles and tendons, cutaneous impulses

path.pathway: skin mechanoreceptors to inferior olivary nucleus to cerebellum
muscle spindles and Golgi tendons to inferior olivary nucleus to cerebellum

tract.name: spinovestibular tract
tract.function: information from cutaneous and proprioceptive organs to CR
tract.source: proprioception information from muscles and tendons, cutaneous impulses

path.pathway: skin mechanoreceptors to vestibular nucleus to cerebellum; C1-C4

tract.name: direct spinocerebellar system
tract.function: spinal cord nuclei to cerebellum
tract.notes: lower are dorsal and ventral SC tracts; upper are cuneocerebellar and rostral spinocerebellar tract

tract.name: cuneocerebellar tract
tract.function: relay information about limb position and movement to the cerebellum
tract.notes: upper extremity equivalent of Clarkes column to CR tract - posterior spinocerebellar tract
tract.target: cerebellum, vermis and paravermis of the ipsilateral posterior lobe

path.pathway: upper limb muscles to accessory cuneate nucleus to cerebellum

tract.name: dorsal spinocerebellar tract
tract.function: conveys proprioceptive information from proprioceptors in the skeletal muscles and joints to the cerebellum
tract.notes: ipsilateral, proprioceptive and tactile information
tract.source: neuromuscular spindles and Golgi tendon organs, joint receptors, cutaneous receptors, lower limbs, below L3

path.pathway: lower limb muscles to clarkes nucleus to cerebellum

tract.name: rostral spinocerebellar tract
tract.function: transmits information from the golgi tendon organs of the cranial half of the body to the cerebellum
tract.notes: upper extremity equivalent of ventral spinocerebellar tract

path.pathway: upper limb muscles to centrobasalis nucleus to cerebellum

tract.name: ventral spinocerebellar tract
tract.function: conveys information about postural stability of the lower limbs to cerebellum
tract.notes: bilaterally, double cross, proprioceptive/fine touch/vibration
tract.source: neuromuscular spindles and Golgi tendon organs, trunk, C8-L3

path.pathway: body muscles to intermediomedial nucleus to cerebellum

tract.name: flexor somatic system
tract.function: control flexor muscles

tract.name: lateral corticospinal tract
tract.function: flexor motor, pyramidal tract, conscious; volitional skilled motor activity
tract.target: muscle groups that require concentration and conscious thought to control; upper limb digits
tract.notes: 90 percents of corticospinal fibers; 80 percents - contrallateral; 10 percents - unilateral; cervical-medial, thoracic, lumbar-lateral, distal muscles, decussating to contralateral and ipsilateral

path.pathway: cortex to spinal cord PM
cortex to spinal cord PL
cortex to spinal cord RPL

tract.name: corticobulbar tract
tract.function: carrying the motor function of the non-oculomotor cranial nerves
tract.notes: V, VII, XI, and XII; indirectly - via IX and X in nucleus ambiguus

path.pathway: cortex to face muscles
cortex to jaw muscles
cortex to tongue muscles
cortex to neck muscles
cortex to throat muscles

tract.name: rubrospinal tract
tract.function: mediation of voluntary movement, upper limbs; control of flexor tone
tract.notes: extrapyramidal; activates flexors, inhibits extensors; pattern locomotion, inhibit reflex activity in spinal cord

path.pathway: cerebellum to red nucleus

path.function: conscious modulation of automatic flexors activity
path.pathway: cortex to red nucleus
red nucleus to spinal cord PM
red nucleus to spinal cord PL
red nucleus to spinal cord RPL

tract.name: extensor somatic system
tract.function: control extensor muscles

tract.name: anterior corticospinal tract
tract.function: extensor motor, pyramidal tract, conscious
tract.notes: premotor BA 6, parietal BA 1,2,3

path.pathway: premotor cortex to spinal cord VM
premotor cortex to spinal cord VL

tract.name: reticulospinal system
tract.function: locomotion and postural control
tract.notes: extrapyramidal; proximal muscles, postural control; integrates information from the motor systems to coordinate automatic movements of locomotion and posture; facilitates and inhibits voluntary movement; influences muscle tone; mediates autonomic functions; modulates pain impulses; influences blood flow to lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus

tract.name: pontine reticulospinal tract
tract.function: exciting anti-gravity, extensor muscles

tract.name: medullary reticulospinal tract
tract.function: inhibiting excitatory axial extensor muscles of movement

tract.name: medial longitudinal fasciculus system
tract.function: connects the cranial nerve nuclei III (oculomotor nerve), IV (trochlear nerve) and VI (abducens nerve) together, and integrates movements directed by the gaze centers (frontal eye field) and information about head movement (from cranial nerve VIII, vestibulocochlear nerve)
tract.notes: connects together III, IV, and VI; integral component of saccadic eye movements as well as vestibulo-ocular and optokinetic reflexes; tectospinal and vestibulospinal

tract.name: vestibulospinal tract
tract.function: alter muscle tone, extend, and change position of limbs and head with goal of supporting posture and maintaining balance of body and head; maintain balance and to stabilize the visual image on the retina during head movements
tract.notes: extrapyramidal; proximal muscles, postural control; activates extensors, inhibits flexors; vestibular nuclei receive their primary input from the vestibular portion of C.N. VIII - vestibular-auditory

tract.name: lateral vestibulospinal tract
tract.source: lateral vestibular nucleus; additional input from superior and inferior vestibular nuclei
tract.function: maintain an upright and balanced posture by stimulating extensor motor neurons in legs
tract.notes: also innervates muscles of the trunk, thus additionally aiding in body posture; lateral vestibular nuclei receive input from cerebellum

tract.name: medial vestibulospinal tract
tract.target: spinal accessory nucleus, paramedian pontine reticular formation
tract.function: controls position of the head, neck, and eyes in response to changes in posture
tract.notes: controlling lower motor neurons associated with the spinal accessory nerve - CN XI; additionally, projects superiorly to the paramedian pontine reticular formation, indirectly innervating the nuclei of CN VI and III

tract.name: tectospinal tract
tract.function: mediate reflex postural movements of head in response to visual and auditory stimuli
tract.notes: extrapyramidal; in response to bright and sudden movements and loud noises

tract.name: autonomic tracts system
tract.function: directs activity of glands, smooth muscles, and cardiac muscle

tract.name: hypothalamospinal tract
tract.function: control autonomic components
tract.target: IML, sympathetic and parasympathetic preganglionic neurons; ciliospinal center of IML (T1,T2)
tract.notes: descend in dorsolateral funiculus; oculosympathetic pathway; next to superior cervical ganglion to common carotid - internal carotid - long ciliary nerves to pupillary dilator

tract.name: solitariospinal system
tract.function: autonomic control of breathing
tract.notes: respiratory, vomiting and micturition functions

tract.name: solitariospinal inpiratory tract
tract.function: facilitate inspiratory motor neurons in phrenic nucleus
tract.source: kolliker-fuse nucleus, receptors to solitary nucleus
tract.notes: neck muscles, external intercostal muscles - conscious forced inspiration; pneumotaxic center = medial parabrachial nucleus + kolliker-fuse nucleus, breathing frequency

tract.name: solitariospinal expiratory tract
tract.function: facilitate expiratory motor neurons to intercostal muscles
tract.source: parabrachial nucleus to nucleus ambiguus, nucleus retroambiguus
tract.target: internal intercostal muscles and abdominal muscles
tract.notes: nucleus ambiguus - cranial division innervates muscles of the ipsilateral accessory muscles of respiration, principally via the vagus; nucleus retroambiguus - caudal division provides inspiratory and expiratory drive to the motor neurones of the intercostal muscles
